title-group.article-title: Is Indirect Calorimetry a Necessity or a Luxury in the Pediatric Intensive Care Unit?

abstract.p: Background: Critically ill children differ in their energy needs from healthy children in terms of underlying metabolic derangement, comorbidities, energy reserve, and response to illness. This study determined how many pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) patients were candidates for indirect calorimetry (IC), per American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition (A.S.P.E.N.) recommendations. Methods: Admission diagnosis, demographics, type/amount of nutrition support, length of intensive care unit/hospital stay were collected. Patients were classified as candidates for IC per A.S.P.E.N. guidelines. Results: Mean (SD) age of patients (n = 150) was 6.7 (5.6) years, with PICU length of stay of 3.9 (5.3) days. IC was indicated in 72.0% (108/150) of patients during PICU days 1–7. Patients with miscellaneous (50%), neurological (73%), respiratory (81%), sepsis (83%), and oncology (100%) diagnoses were candidates for IC. Underweight/overweight/obese (32.4%), hypermetabolism (26.4%), and not meeting nutrition goals (13.7%) were the most frequent indications for IC (χ2, P < .001). Patients (31%) met ≥2 indications for IC. Patients with neurological disease (relative risk [RR], 4.8; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.7–14.6), oncology patients (4.2; 1.1–15.9), respiratory patients (5.5; 2.0–16.9), and children with sepsis/septic shock/infection (5.6; 1.9–18.1) were more likely to have ≥2 indications for IC compared to those with other diagnoses. Conclusions: Three of 4 patients were candidates for IC per A.S.P.E.N. guidelines. PICUs might have to prioritize performing IC in patients who are <2 years of age, malnourished (underweight/overweight) on admission, or PICU stay of >5 days. Future studies should determine the cost-benefit ratios of performing IC in PICU patients.

sec.title: Clinical Relevancy Statement
sec.p: Critically ill children in the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) differ in their energy needs from healthy children in terms of underlying metabolism and growth, comorbidities, and preexisting energy reserve, and this makes it difficult to estimate energy needs in these patients. Estimates of energy expenditure using available standard equations are often unreliable. True energy needs can be determined only by measuring energy expenditure with indirect calorimetry (IC). This preliminary study determined how many PICU patients would be candidates for IC, based on current recommendations by the American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Critically ill children, especially infants, in the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) are at high risk of developing nutrition deficiencies, altered nutrition status, and anthropometric changes that may lead to increased morbidity.1,2 Acute injury, inflammation, surgery, or sepsis markedly alters energy needs by inducing hyper- and hypometabolic conditions3-5 that may be present in a single patient at different time points in the continuum of care. It is essential to provide the appropriate energy, substrate distribution, and micronutrients necessary to support the ongoing metabolic and stress response to avoid the loss of critical lean body mass and worsening of any existing nutrient deficiencies.1,2

Given that critically ill children differ in their energy needs from their healthy counterparts, predictive equations are often unreliable.6-9 To accurately account for the dynamic alterations in energy metabolism during critical illness, measured resting energy expenditure via indirect calorimetry (IC) remains the gold standard to determine energy needs in this population. This is supported by recent American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition (A.S.P.E.N.) guidelines10 suggesting IC measurements be obtained when possible in pediatric patients with suspected metabolic alterations or malnutrition. These guidelines go on to state special attention should be given to any imbalance between energy intake and expenditure to prevent over- and underfeeding in this population6,11 given the potential for adverse consequences. Given the flux of energy requirements during the course of critical illness, it is also recommended repeated measures be performed on a timely basis.10

Unfortunately, the lack of monetary resources and/or technical expertise often limits the availability of IC in many PICUs. In the recent guidelines,10 A.S.P.E.N. outlined a list of criteria that, when present, may lead to metabolic alterations that make standardized equations even less reliable. It was suggested these patients may benefit from targeted IC measurements to avoid over- or underfeeding.10 To obtain the necessary data to campaign for the availability of IC in our PICU, we performed a prospective chart review to determine the number of patients who would benefit from IC measurements during their first week of stay according to the A.S.P.E.N. guidelines. We hypothesized that >50% of patients admitted to the PICU would meet these criteria.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This prospective chart review of 150 consecutive patients was conducted in the PICU from June to August 2010. All patients admitted to the PICU during a 7-week period were included prospectively within 24 hours of admission. Patients with very short intensive care unit (ICU) stays were also included, as long as they were physically present in the unit at the time of enrollment. There were no exclusion criteria. The data, collected in a de-identified manner, included primary and secondary admission diagnosis, use of mechanical ventilation, vasoactive or neuromuscular drugs, vital signs, age, height, weight, body mass index (BMI), Pediatric Risk of Mortality Score (PRISM),12 Pediatric Logic Organ Dysfunction Score (PELOD),13,14 nutrition support, and length of ICU and hospital stay. Underweight, overweight, and obesity were defined as <5th, 85th–95th, and >95th percentile based on Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) weight for height growth chart for children age <2 years and BMI chart for children age >2 years. The nutrition intake data were collected prospectively each morning for the previous 24 hours for the duration of the PICU stay or 7 days, whichever was longer. All intravenous (IV; D5, D10), parenteral nutrition (PN; volume, content), and enteral nutrition (EN; product and volume given, concentration, etc) were recorded. Energy and protein intake were calculated for each day by a registered dietitian. Days on which patients received oral (PO) intake (29%; 138/476 patient days) were excluded from the analysis because total accurate energy and protein intake could not be assessed for these days. • Oncologic diagnoses (including children with stem cell or bone marrow transplant)
• Children requiring mechanical ventilatory support for >7 days

• Children suspected to be severely hypermetabolic (status epilepticus, hyperthermia, systemic inflammatory response syndrome, dysautonomic storms, etc) or hypometabolic (hypothermia, hypothyroidism, pentobarbital or midazolam coma, etc)

sec.p: Patients meeting these criteria are suggested candidates for targeted measurements for resting energy expenditure (REE) in the PICU.

All patients were evaluated for systemic inflammatory response syndrome, using the criteria by Goldstein et al.16 For patients who were suspected to be hypermetabolic or hypometabolic, the dietitian, in collaboration with the bedside physician, made a clinical judgment based on diagnosis and clinical status.

For analysis purposes, some of the IC indications were combined as follows: underweight, overweight, and obesity were combined as “underweight/overweight/obese,” and mechanical ventilation for >7 days, failure to wean or increase in respiratory support, and neuroblockers for >7 days were also combined as “mechanical ventilation.” For the purpose of this analysis, failure to wean or need to escalate respiratory support included patients who required an increase in mean airway pressure or minute ventilation or use of high-frequency oscillator ventilation.
The study was approved by the Baylor College of Medicine Institutional Review Board, which granted a waiver of informed consent for this study.

sec.title: Statistics
sec.p: Patients who met <2 A.S.P.E.N. criteria for IC were compared to those with ≥2 A.S.P.E.N. criteria. Normally distributed continuous variables were compared using paired and unpaired t test and analysis of variance (ANOVA). Nonnormally distributed variables were compared by the Mann-Whitney U-test or Kruskal-Wallis test. Categorical variables were compared using the χ2 test or Fisher exact test. Relative risk, with 95% confidence intervals (CIs), was calculated by the Fisher exact test for a 2 × 2 contingency table. Statistical significance was defined as P < .05. Statistical analysis was performed with Statview and JMP (SAS Institute, Inc, Cary, NC).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Characteristics of patients with <2 and ≥2 indications for IC are shown in Table 2. The mean (SD) age of patients (n = 150; male/female, 56%/44%) was 6.7 (5.6) years. More patients with ≥2 indications for IC required mechanical ventilation and inotropes, and they had higher PELOD and longer PICU and hospital length of stay (LOS) than patients with <2 indications for IC. Patients with <2 and ≥2 indications for IC were hospitalized for neurological problems/seizure disorders (20.0% and 12.0%), respiratory diagnoses (13.3% and 10.7%), sepsis/septic shock/infection (6.7% and 5.3%), oncology (4.0% and 2.0%), and miscellaneous diagnoses (24.0% and 2.0%), respectively (Table 2). Survival was 96.0% at hospital discharge.

sec.p: More patients older than 12 years (38.1%) were overweight or obese than those 2–12 years (28.8%) or <2 years (16.7%) (Table 3). On the other hand, more patients <2 years (21.4%) than those 2–12 or >12 years (4.5% and 11.9%, respectively) were underweight.

sec.p: There were no significant differences for suggested IC indication between gender (male/female, 76% vs 67%, χ2, P = .20) and age groups (<2 years, 74%; 2–12 years, 65%; and >12 years, 81%; χ2, P = .20). The 150 patients in this study had 182 indications for IC as suggested by A.S.P.E.N. guidelines (Table 4). IC was indicated in 72% (108/150) of patients. By diagnostic category, 50%, 73%, 81%, 83%, and 100% of patients with miscellaneous, neurological, respiratory, sepsis, and oncology diagnoses were candidates for IC, respectively. Underweight/overweight/obese (32.4%), hypermetabolism (26.4%), not meeting nutrition goals (13.7%), and mechanical ventilation (11.5%) were the most frequent indications for IC (χ2, P < .001). Patients with neurological/seizure and respiratory disorders were responsible for 66% of the suggested indications for IC.

sec.p: A total of 31% of patients had ≥2 and 5% of patients had ≥4 indications for IC. There was a significant association between diagnostic categories and ≥2 indications for IC (Table 5). Patients with neurological disorders (relative risk [RR], 4.8; 95% CI, 1.7–14.6), respiratory patients (5.5; 2.0–16.9), and children with sepsis/septic shock/infection (5.6; 1.9–18.1) had a higher relative risk to have ≥2 indications for IC compared to patients with miscellaneous diagnoses.

sec.p: Underfeeding, based on the Schofield equation, was very common in our patients because patients were NPO (nil per os) for 43.5% (n = 207/476) of patient days, and energy intake met <90% of Schofield in 71.6% (247/346) of patient days. The incidence of underfeeding was greater in patients aged ≥12 years and 2–12 years than in those <2 years, with 91%, 75%, and 59% of patient days, respectively, meeting <90% of Schofield (χ2, P < .001). Furthermore, 20.5% (71/346) of patient days met ≥110% (data not shown) and 9.2% (32/346) of patient days met ≥150% of estimated energy needs in our patients.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: To our knowledge, this is the first study to evaluate the percentage of patients admitted to a PICU with 1 or more criteria that suggest a high risk for metabolic alterations as outlined in the A.S.P.E.N. guidelines.10 We prospectively found that 3 of 4 patients were identified as candidates for IC, and 1 of 3 patients met ≥2 A.S.P.E.N. suggested criteria for IC. We categorized patients as meeting <2 and ≥2 A.S.P.E.N. criteria to not only evaluate patients at high risk for metabolic alterations but also further identify how many patients qualified for IC with more than 1 criterion, which would indicate a stronger need to obtain IC measurements. A.S.P.E.N., as part of the A.S.P.E.N. Guidelines on Nutrition Support of the Critically Ill Child,10 recommended that, in a subgroup of patients with suspected metabolic alterations or malnutrition, accurate measurement of energy expenditure using IC is desirable.

sec.title: Indications for Indirect Calorimetry
sec.p: Several small studies have demonstrated the variability of the metabolic state17 and the uniform failure of estimated energy needs in predicting the measured REE in critically ill children.6-9 Thus, true energy needs can be determined only by measuring energy expenditure with IC. The cumulative effects of inaccurate estimations and suboptimal delivery may result in significant caloric imbalances in critically ill children18 and predispose critically ill children to the risk of overfeeding and underfeeding.6,11 To decrease the risks of over- and underfeeding, A.S.P.E.N. developed criteria for targeting a select group of children in the PICU for IC measurement of REE and suggested that “these criteria may be useful for centers with limited resources for metabolic testing.”10 A.S.P.E.N. suggested that “the selective application of IC may allow many units to balance the need for accurate REE measurements and limited resources.”10 In the current study, we identified that 72% of the patients admitted to our PICU had 1 or more A.S.P.E.N. criteria suggesting they would be candidates for IC measurements. Underweight/overweight/obese, hypermetabolism, and not meeting nutrition goals were the most frequent indications for IC (Table 4). Patients with sepsis/septic shock/infections, respiratory disease, and neurological disorders were significantly more likely to have ≥2 indications for IC than patients with miscellaneous diagnoses (Table 5).

A.S.P.E.N. developed the presented criteria with the intent to help practitioners target PICU patients who would most benefit from IC measurements, given the potential for the inability to perform IC on all patients secondary to a lack of resources. In the present study, 72% of our patients would have benefited from IC measurements; unfortunately, this exceeds our available manpower and resources. Until appropriate resources are available, practitioners may need to further prioritize their patients according to their risk categories. The following examples suggest age, presence of malnutrition, and length of PICU stay may be used as narrowing criteria. Pollack et al19,20 identified critically ill children <2 years of age at an increased risk of developing nutrition deficiencies given their high basal metabolic rate and limited energy reserves. At present, there are limited data regarding IC in children, other than neonates, given the challenges with performing the measurements (such as use of specialized equipment; technical support; high settings on conventional mechanical ventilation, including FiO2 >60% or high positive end-expiratory pressure [PEEP]; use of a high-frequency oscillator; chest tubes with air leak; and an inability to obtain steady state during the IC measurement). According to a study by De Wit et al,21 patients with poor nutrition status may have higher REE, putting them at risk for worsening nutrition status if underfed. Furthermore, patients with longer length of stay have been shown to be the “sickest”22 and thus perhaps at a greater risk for energy imbalances and developing nutrition deficiencies.

sec.title: Under- and Overweight and Over- and Underfeeding in PICU Patients
sec.p: A significant proportion of our patients was under- and overweight. Patients older than 12 years were more likely to be overweight or obese than younger patients (Table 3). This may be a reflection of the higher prevalence of obesity in children of this age. On the other hand, more patients <2 years were underweight than older children, which could be explained by the higher incidence of children with chronic diseases in our population (unpublished data).

Our study also showed that underfeeding based on the Schofield equation appears to be a significant problem in the early days of the PICU stay, and cumulative energy deficits may be significant in pediatric patients.17 Significant underfeeding with prolonged negative nitrogen balance can exacerbate existing malnutrition and may extend hospital stay and lead to recurrent illness.23 PICUs should, therefore, address the barriers to meeting energy and protein nutrition goals whether energy expenditure was determined by IC or estimated based on standard equations.

Overfeeding has been previously reported in a study of PICU patients24 who were hospitalized for a median PICU LOS of 44 days and included 45% of children <1 year of age. We found that energy intake in our patients exceeded >110% and >150% of estimated energy needs based on the Schofield equation for 20.5% (71/346) and 9.2% (32/346) of patient days, respectively. Energy intakes in excess of 140%−150% of BMR should be avoided, unless IC is available to document higher energy needs and there is evidence of poor growth. However, accurate energy needs can be determined only by IC.

sec.title: Study Limitations
sec.p: The present study was an observational study. No intervention (IC) occurred. In addition, subjective clinical judgment was used to determine which patients were at risk of hyper- or hypometabolism. The study did not discuss the impact of clinical conditions that prevent accurate IC measurements, such as with air leaks secondary to chest tubes or failure to achieve steady state during IC, or that may lead to inaccurate measurements, such as with O2 delivery >60%, high PEEP, use of a high-frequency oscillator, or extracorporeal membrane oxygenator support. Because not all of these data were kept for the database, the actual number of patients who meet feasibility and eligibility may be lower than that described by looking for 1 or more criteria.

Future studies should confirm our results with larger study samples and longer study periods. Prospective studies of IC in critically ill pediatric patients are urgently needed. Longer follow-up may also be necessary to identify other potential problems, including overfeeding.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In our study, we concluded that 3 of 4 patients were candidates for IC given they had 1 or more criteria suggested in the A.S.P.E.N. guidelines as indicative of high risk of metabolic alterations. Further prioritization of patients with age (<2 years), weight (underweight [<90%] or overweight [>120% of desired weight range]), or PICU LOS (>5 days) restrictions in addition to the A.S.P.E.N. criteria may be necessary when resources limit the availability of IC use.
Future studies will need to determine the cost-benefit ratios of performing IC in critically ill patients.
